With respect, your naivety is astounding! Why would any member of an advanced intraterrestrial or extraterrestrial civilization want to communicate with someone of your limited intellectual capabilities? I am not trying to insult you. I'm just stating a fact. You don't even know the true history of your planet, let alone how it is managed. Furthermore, your knowledge of astronomy is based on primitive concepts which, in a few centuries, will be regarded with the same disdain as that of modern physicists who laugh at the notion that the Earth was believed to be the centre of the universe by medieval astronomers.


THE EMERGENCE OF EXTRATERRESTRIAL LIFE WAS INEVITABLE

If a universal God exists and it created ideal conditions for life to evolve only on Earth then this God would not be very intelligent. What intelligent God would create a fertile planet surrounded by a vast and sterile universe? The reality of the situation is that the four known forces which govern the behaviour of matter and energy are calibrated to such a degree of perfection that it is inconceivable that they were not predetermined to create the conditions for life to appear in all its various forms throughout the universe. Intellectually and mathematically, the postulate that life exists only on Earth is both naive and absurd. But if intelligent extraterrestrial life exists in the Galaxy, why have they not contacted us? Where are they located and what would they look like? These are the questions that have always been asked by an uninformed public. Unfortunately the people most qualified to answer these questions such as biologists, physicists, philosophers, chemists, astronomers and religious intellectuals have, for the most part, always claimed that we are alone in the Universe. Historically they have always been wrong because they have not had access to all the information that exists on the subject which is reserved only for a minority of privileged and very powerful people in the world and unfortunately that does not include you.


I find it amusing that people like you don't even realize that Earth was conquered long ago and is in a region of the galaxy dominated by a species called the Alpha Draconians. Impossible you say? Not necessarily! So how would a hostile species tackle the problem of dominating another species? It is probable that the preferred method of controlling a planet for a highly intelligent and technologically advanced malevolent race of extraterrestrials would be covert infiltration rather than by obvious and violent force. Moreover, as a general rule, one does not destroy what one can control so the most logical strategy would be to control the leadership of the planet, its political, military and economic establishments but more importantly, the secret societies, affiliations and clubs which control these establishments. Conquering a species that doesn't know it has been conquered is the mark of superior intelligence. Obviously some people may doubt the existence of malevolent extraterrestrials in the first place. Why would they exist at all? The answer is that the universe would be a much less interesting and dynamic place if various species were not pushed to their limits in order to survive and evolve. Without conflict and struggle to survive in highly competitive environments, there would be no incentive to adapt and change. As a consequence, the process of evolution would slow down dramatically and the plethora of unique species that exist today would also decrease significantly. For intelligent and technological species, this eternal struggle is a philosophical one between the precepts of malevolence and benevolence. In other words between the desire to dominate other species or being subjugated oneself. It would also be the contrast between autocratic self-serving behaviour or believing in freedom, equality and democracy. Ironically without the existence of emotions in many extraterrestrial species in the universe, it is doubtful that benevolent species would exist at all because if all actions and behaviour are deemed to be acceptable without limits, then the emergence of a code of ethics cannot occur. In a certain sense, this philosophical struggle corresponds to the yin and yang in Chinese philosophy which describes how apparently opposite and contrary forces are actually complementary. More precisely, each serves as a reference point for the other. Fortunately the capacity for emotions such as pleasure and pain serve as a strong foundation for the emergence of a code of ethics among most intelligent species in the universe.


Hopefully you will now understand that the universe is teeming with life. It has always been this way and will always be this way. I cannot expect you to understand why these cycles are eternal because your brain is psychologically programmed to understand absolutes and quantifiable events in finite terms. In this context the belief that the universe is approximately 13 billion years old and has boundaries is both charming and inaccurate.

nothing like a kurzgesagt video to make you feel insignificant and special at the same time. On another note, our DNA is related to the first organism...sort of. Considering DNA as it is today, it is unlikely that any significantly long series relates back to the first organism. In your body, as a cell divides, a few thousand errors are made. Most are fixed by specialized proteins, but some remain. Luckily for us, not all of our DNA encodes for things, so we do not end up with highly irregular cells from everyday experience. However, the mutation rate is high enough that over long enough periods of time, nearly everything changes at least a little bit. So, it's really unlikely that your DNA resembles anything like the first organism's DNA and probably anything more than about a billion years old.

Actually, we could survive after the last star goes out.

Black holes can convert matter to energy far more efficiently than stars. If you created a subatomic black hole and fed it steadily with a planet then absorbed lets say 5% of its resulting output (as hawking radiation) then you'd be able to give yourself the equivalent power we use on earth in a year every second for trillions of years.

If you created a charged black hole you could confine it with its magnetic field, build the power-capturing shell and then live on top of it in an artificial ecosystem.
With the conservation of energy I would argue that ( if we play our cards right ) we can survive without the sun.

I've just rediscovered my favourite reason to live. Our bodies are just amalgamates of atoms that have come together in such a finely calibrated way, sentience was just RANDOMLY able to happen! Knowing that the universe and our earth are constantly reusing and redistributing the same atoms over and over again to create anything at all is incredible! In an infinite continuum of time and space, the random series of cosmic events happened at just the right time, in just the right quantity and speed for us to be able to exist and think and feel so many things that extend beyond all human perception. And we're just here, experiencing it for ourselves as our tiny, little planet hurtles through the universe, tagging along with our Sun, doing our own thing in the forefront and unravelling the mysteries of the universe to fit our own understanding.

Like, this is so rambly, but when you've come to the conclusion that nothing in our lives or the universe matters due to the gaping emptiness that comes from the fact that all of this is random, I'm always taken aback by how incredible just existing actually is when you remember that this is what we are, for better or worse. There are few people who experience the true melancholy of being alone - I'm one of them. Try to imagine what it would be like to live from cradle to grave KNOWING that no one wants you - to die a dateless virgin, a loser, undesirable - I'm one of them. I speak for that small percentage of people out there who can relate. Being alone and dying alone is probably the one, worst fate that a human can suffer - I'm one of them. I've lost track on how many times girls have told me that "I wasn't their type" - that's PC for "you're ugly as fuck and I wouldn't spread my legs for you if you were the last guy on earth" - alright so be it. Some people try to tell me that there are nice girls out there - I can't believe that, from my experience they're already taken and even if they weren't, I'd still get the above excuse. Do you know what it's like to be treated negatively because of your race, skin color? Well, I suffer a double whammy for being a half-breed - people react to me as if they don't know how they should relate to me and girls won't date a guy who is racially ambiguous. Some people have tried to help, but it's all just pep talk and I'm sure there are many who will jump at the chance to kick a guy when he's down - but I say this to you, you can't hurt a guy who's got nothing left to lose....

Theory on how we exist:

Time itself is treated as linear. Assume that at some point in the future we as a species find a way to travel through time. The universe is at the point where the last star is about to go out. We then use that time machine to travel back to the start of the universe, cheating death and allowing for evolution to continue and proceed to colonise the universe again. A large period of time passes, different groups of humans have settled all across the universe and evolve differently, diverging into new species. Due to such a length of time passing these groups forget about eachother and become alien to one and other. During this time one group finds its way to this earth and starts life here where it will evolve into what we regognise. No you may be saying it creates paradoxes, well yes. but at that point where we go back to the start of the universe a separate timeline is created, this process goes on infinitely.

We are here and we are going to go to the stars - unless we all get nuked - but I'm optimistic (that means we wont). The next question is: We can't be the first intelligent life to get this far in the Galaxy in the last 10 billion years. Where are the others?

The simplest way would be to use self replicating probes that rebuild more probes when they find any available resources. Exploring this way would cover the entire Milky Way galaxy in less than 100 million years. So where are they?
Hiding you say? But what for? There is no freaking good reason, after travelling so far to then hide!

There are only a few possibilities: 1 We are not what advanced space faring folk are looking for, for whatever reasons. 2  We are not considered worth contacting, either for our lack of intelligence or, they are similar to us and realise the damaging cultural consequences of premature exposure to extra-terrestrials. 3 There is no-one out there.

I think it is of the utmost importance to behave as if we are the only intelligent life bearing planet in the galaxy. And work together to avoid the very real danger, that the reason there are no other advance living creatures out there, is because by the time they have developed advanced technology, they fail to prevent their own extinction. It is becoming very obvious that Earth is in this same situation. Either we save the planet, or the Planet will do it - at our expense.

A very small percentage of the elements found in the Universe were created from Supernovae. This is one big common misconception. An overwhelming majority of the atoms were created during the Big Bang (which in itself is a theory but one backed with lots of data). You could also think of it this way. There are an unimaginable number of atoms in the universe. If all those atoms were supplied by Supernovae, then Supernovae should be a very common and regular occurrence in the Universe and we should be able to observe them frequently in our own galaxy and other galaxies but actual statistical data does not support this. Supernovae are actually rare so there's no way they alone could supply a majority of the atoms of the Universe. There have to other sources.

? About the Fine Tuning as the absolute proof of a Mind.

The fine-tuning argument

The argument goes like this:

The fine-tuning of the universe to support life is either due to law, chance or design
It is not due to law or chance

Therefore, the fine-tuning is due to design

What does it meaning to be fine-tuned for life?

Here are the facts on the fine-tuning:

Life has certain minimal requirements;

long-term stable source of energy, a large number of different chemical elements, an element that can serve as a hub for joining together other elements into compounds, etc.
In order to meet these minimal requirements, the physical constants, (such as the gravitational constant), and the ratios between physical constants, need to be withing a narrow range of values in order to support the minimal requirements for life of any kind.
Slight changes to any of the physical constants, or to the rations between the constants, will result in a universe inhospitable to life.

The range of possible ranges over 70 orders of magnitude.

The constants are selected by whoever creates the universe. They are not determined by physical laws. And the extreme probabilities involved required put the fine-tuning beyond the reach of chance.

Although each individual selection of constants and ratios is as unlikely as any other selection, the vast majority of these possibilities do not support the minimal requirements of life of any kind. (In the same way as any hand of 5 cards that is dealt is as likely as any other, but you are overwhelmingly likely NOT to get a royal flush. In our case, a royal flush is a life-permitting universe).

Examples of finely-tuned constants

Here are a couple of examples of the fine-tuning. Craig only gave one example in the debate and didn’t explain how changes to the constant would affect the minimal requirements for life. But Bradley does explain it, and he is a professional research scientist, so he is speaking about things he worked in his polymer research lab. (He was the director)

a) The strong force: (the force that binds nucleons (= protons and neutrons) together in nucleus, by means of meson exchange)
if the strong force constant were 2% stronger, there would be no stable hydrogen, no long-lived stars, no hydrogen containing compounds. This is because the single proton in hydrogen would want to stick to something else so badly that there would be no hydrogen left!
if the strong force constant were 5% weaker, there would be no stable stars, few (if any) elements besides hydrogen. This is because you would be able to build up the nuclei of the heavier elements, which contain more than 1 proton.
So, whether you adjust the strong force up or down, you lose stars than can serve as long-term sources of stable energy, or you lose chemical diversity, which is necessary to make beings that can perform the minimal requirements of living beings. (see below)

b) The conversion of beryllium to carbon, and carbon to oxygen
Life requires carbon in order to serve as the hub for complex molecules, but it also requires oxygen in order to create water.
Carbon is like the hub wheel in a tinker toy set: you can bind other elements together to more complicated molecules (e.g. – “carbon-based life), but the bonds are not so tight that they can’t be broken down again later to make something else.
The carbon resonance level is determined by two constants: the strong force and electromagnetic force.
If you mess with these forces even slightly, you either lose the carbon or the oxygen.
Either way, you’ve got no life of any conceivable kind.

Is the fine-tuning real?

Yes, it’s real and it is conceded by the top-rank of atheist physicists. Let me give you a citation from the best one of all, Martin Rees. Martin Rees is an atheist and a qualified astronomer. He wrote a book called “Just Six Numbers:

The Deep Forces That Shape The Universe”, (Basic Books: 2001). In it, he discusses 6 numbers that need to be fine-tuned in order to have a life-permitting universe.

Rees writes here:

These six numbers constitute a ‘recipe’ for a universe. Moreover, the outcome is sensitive to their values: if any one of them were to be ‘untuned’, there would be no stars and no life. Is this tuning just a brute fact, a coincidence?

Or is it the providence of a benign Creator?

There are some atheists who deny the fine-tuning, but these atheists are in firm opposition to the progress of science. The more science has progressed, the more constants, ratios and quantities we have discovered that need to be fine-tuned. Science is going in a theistic direction. Next, let’s see how atheists try to account for the fine-tuning, on atheism.

Atheistic responses to the fine-tuning argument

There are two common responses among atheists to this argument.

The first is to speculate that there are actually an infinite number of other universes that are not fine-tuned, (i.e. – the gambler’s fallacy). All these other universes don’t support life. We just happen to be in the one universe is fine-tuned for life. The problem is that there is no way of directly observing these other universes and no independent evidence that they exist.

Here is an excerpt from an article in Discover magazine, (which is hostile to theism and Christianity).

http://discovermagazine.com/2008/dec/10-sciences-alternative-to-an-intelligent-creator

The second response by atheists is that the human observers that exist today, 14 billion years after the universe was created out of nothing, actually caused the fine-tuning. This solution would mean that although humans did not exist at the time the of the big bang, they are going to be able to reach back in time at some point in the future and manually fine-tune the universe.
Here is an excerpt from and article in the New Scientist, (which is hostile to theism and Christianity).

www.newscientist.com/article/mg20026852.500-why-its-not-as-simple-as-god-vs-the-multiverse.html

So, there are two choices for atheists. Either an infinite number of unobservable universes that are not fine-tuned, or humans go back in time at some future point and fine-tune the beginning of the universe, billions of years in the past.

That we are here by chance is meaningful. We are either here by intention or not, if not then by definition we are here by chance.
What we have is evidence for fine-tuning. You don’t dispute that. What you dispute is what the evidence means. There are only two possibilities: chance or not chance, if not chance then we are here by intention. You have to ask yourself which of the two, given the evidence we have, is more plausible. Intention is clearly more plausible due to analogous reasoning. There is no reason to believe that fine-tuning is the result of chance. The only reason why people believe that it’s just a coincidence is because they wish to believe it.

1. like causes like effects
2. the effect of fine-tuning is caused by intelligence
3. Therefore, I think there is not enough evidence to choose between chance or intelligence.

While this is a fantastic video (like all of your content) there is one error: Stars die long before all of their hydrogen is expended. In stars only the innermost 10% (or so) is hot and dense enough for the fusion of hydrogen into helium. Since this helium is heavier than the hydrogen it collects in the middle. Over time is helium pushes the hydrogen outwards. After about 10 to 15 billion years (for a sun sized star) so much helium has accumulated that the hydrogen is so far out that it can no longer fuse. When this happens small and medium stars like the sun transition to red giants and begin to die (eventually forming white dwarfs), while the largest stars continue to fuse heavier and heavier elements. When these massive stars reach iron they collapse, because iron consumes energy when fused, into neutron stars or black holes.

Thanks so much for this video and every video you guys make!

All the best

Extinction at this point in Humanity's progression is literally impossible. 50 years ago, maybe. but now, there is no natural phenomena which can kill all 7 billion humans. 

An asteroid impact, contrary to popular belief, is very much survivable. The main thing that killed the dinosaurs was the eternal winter that the dust put into the atmosphere by the asteroid caused. Many species of mammals survived it because of their ability to keep warm due to fur, and low energy consumption. Humans could easily survive with our technology. Our coal reserves would last us about as long as the winter. 

As for diseases, even with the most deadly and the most infectious disease mankind has faced, and at the most poor sanitation in human history, the black plague only killed one third to one half of only Europe. With today's modern medicine and modern sanitation, a vaccines can be produced faster than the most resilient and infectious disease humans can concoct. And our ability to make vaccines still doubles every two years. Plus, with natural immunity, it is biologically impossible for us to go extinct by disease. 

The only thing that can kill us, and will kill us, it the Heat Death of the Universe.

"You" is a pattern, not a particular bit of matter.  Even if the parts get replaced every few days, they are replaced piece-for-piece, keeping the overall pattern, you, mostly unchanged.  Like replacing run-down parts in a car.
"You are not alone, you never were, you never will be". :')

The lightest human adults of normal height are only 30 kg, and are mainly people with exceptionally rare diseases or severe eating disorders.

"0.1mm in diameter"
Hmm ok, so a cell has a volume of about (0.1mm)^3
"Today, you consist of about 50 trillion cells"
Alright so 50 trillion * (0.1mm)^3 gives my body a volume of... 50 cubic meters. The size of a freight container. And that's assuming these cells are packed as tightly as possible, when in fact the human body is filled with cavities and empty space.

So this guy was either wrong about the size of a cell by a factor of 12,500,
or the 50 trillion number is false,
or I'm a solid block the size of a train car.

The thing that makes me feel close to humanity and the universe is knowledge, even when I am physically what we call alone. It's beautiful that the atoms that make us up were formed in the core of a star that is now long gone, and that our DNA all stemmed from the one single cell (sidenote: we should call this first lifeform Martin), but the thing that makes me ball-to-the-walls amazed is that all the technology and knowledge that lay before us in this modern era is the culmination of millennia of human efforts - of those long past and those still innovating. It's nice to take a step back every once in a while and think about the billions of people who lived before us - and those less fortunate who live today - who were not quite so blessed.
